title-group.article-title: Options, Taxes, and Ex-Dividend Day Behavior

abstract.p: A novel way of estimating the expected as opposed to the actual share price fall-off is developed using option prices. This method is applied to the UK Traded Options Market using data from 1979 to 1984. The results show that: (a) the average expected fall-off implicit in option prices is around 55 to 60% of the dividend and significantly different from it. The fall-off also varied inversely with the dividend yield, which is consistent with the prediction of the "tax clientele hypothesis." (b) The estimates of the expected fall-off were not significantly different from the actual fall-off. (c) Finally, the results imply that the usual assumption made in valuing options on dividend-paying stocks, that the fall-off is equal to the dividend, would lead to downward-biased estimates of the option value.
